title: 111_s1831
content: The "Small Business Venture Capital Act of 2009" defines key terms related to the Small Business Administration and the New Markets Venture Capital Program under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The "Small Business Venture Capital Act of 2009" defines key terms related to the Small Business Administration and the New Markets Venture Capital Program under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The act includes reauthorization, leverage, private capital, maximum investment in a company, diversification of New Markets Venture Capital Program, establishment of Office of New Markets Venture Capital, low-income geographic areas, applications for New Markets Venture Capital Program, operational assistance grants, and authorization. SEC. 101 of the Small Business Venture Capital Act of 2009 amends Section 20 of the Small Business Act to authorize purchases of participating securities and guarantees of debentures for fiscal years 2010 through 2013. SEC. 102 addresses leverage. Section 303(b)(2) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow investments in small business concerns owned by women and disadvantaged small business concerns. The maximum leverage for a small business investment company is set at 300% of private capital or $175,000,000. The maximum leverage for small business investment companies is set at $250,000,000 if they are commonly controlled and invest at least 50% in women-owned small businesses. Small business investment companies can have a maximum leverage of $250,000,000 if they are commonly controlled and invest at least 50% in women-owned or socially and economically disadvantaged small businesses. SEC. 103 amends the Small Business Investment Act regarding private capital. SEC. 104 increases the maximum investment in a company from 10% to 30%. TITLE II introduces the New Markets Venture Capital Program for diversification. The Small Business Investment Act is amended to include a Geographic Goal for selecting companies in the New Markets Venture Capital program. The Administrator must select at least 1 company from each geographic region. Additionally, participation in the program is now required for the Administrator. The Small Business Investment Act is amended to set a goal of entering into at least 1 agreement each fiscal year with a company primarily engaged in developing and investing in small manufacturers. SEC. 202. Establishment of Office of New Markets Venture Capital under Title II of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Office of New Markets Venture Capital is established within the Small Business Investment Division of the Administration. The Director of the office is appointed by the Administrator and is responsible for administering the New Markets Venture Capital Program, assessing the program regularly, and working to increase participation of small-business concerns. The New Markets Venture Capital Program aims to encourage investment in small manufacturers. SEC. 203. LOW-INCOME GEOGRAPHIC AREAS. Section 351 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to redefine a 'low-income community' as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The definition of "low-income geographic area" under section 351 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include any area. This amended definition applies to capital raised by a New Markets Venture Capital company before, on, or after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 204. The Administrator will create standard application documents for New Markets Venture Capital companies to reduce application costs. SEC. 205. Operational assistance grants will be provided. Section 358(a)(4)(A) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to provide grants to New Markets Venture Capital companies based on private capital raised, capped at $1,000,000. Additionally, Section 354(d) outlines requirements for final approval within 2 years of conditional approval. The company must raise at least $5,000,000 of private capital from investors that meet specific criteria established by the Administrator. Additionally, Section 358(a)(4) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to update references to section 354(d). SEC. 206 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to change the fiscal years to 2010 through 2013 and reduce the amount from $30,000,000 to $20,000,000.
